items.title: python3 error: AttributeError: 'str' object has no attribute 'decode'
items.body:
When websockify (latest master) is run using python3, it generates the following exception when a large amount of binary data is transmitted:

File "websockify/websocket.py", line 572, in _recvmsg
    self._partial_msg = ''.decode("ascii")
AttributeError: 'str' object has no attribute 'decode'

The offending line is:

` self._partial_msg = ''.decode("ascii")
`

Changing it to this works on python3:

`self._partial_msg = '';
`

And strangely the above line also seems to work fine on python2 as well. I'm unclear about the reasons for the decode("ascii"), so for now I'm just running our websockify using python2.

items.title: Possible to serve files alongside Express?
items.body:
I am already using Express to serve a bunch of files and listen on a certain port but in order to integrate noVNC into my application, the use of Websockify appears mandatory. Is there any way to use the Websockify proxy and Express simultaneously? 

How does `Websockify` serve files? http(s)?

What would this look like? 

As I understand it (for noVNC) `Websockify` just grabs the `rfb` object/data from port `5900` and then bridges that to the port on which the files are being served. I don't understand how the `rfb` object is actually received by `vnc_lite.html` (in my case). I have tried to use `Websockify` alongside `Express` just to see what would happen and no surprise that it claims the port is busy. 

I've also considered just letting `Websockify` serve my files but I am hoping to get some sort of confirmation that this will behave similarly to `Express` before I go and change a bunch of stuff.

items.title: TCP stream segmentation into messages?
items.body:
What is websockify's policy for segmenting the TCP response stream into WebSocket messages?  Could you explicitly document this?

items.title: BUG-FIX: websockifyserver.py socket.getaddrinfo port need to be casted to str
items.body:
Dear WebSockify/noVNC Team

Testing noVNC/WebSockify against BaseTokenAPI I found that the connection failed
See: https://github.com/novnc/noVNC/issues/1250
 
The problem was "port" attribute of socket.getaddrinfo on websockifyserver.py (line: 461)

**From:**
`addrs = socket.getaddrinfo(host, port, 0, socket.SOCK_STREAM,`

**To:**
`addrs = socket.getaddrinfo(host, int(port), 0, socket.SOCK_STREAM,`

**Patch** (diff -Naur websockifyserver.py.original websockifyserver.py) **:**

```
--- websockifyserver.py.original        2019-06-10 11:58:46.040671247 +0200
+++ websockifyserver.py 2019-06-10 11:57:53.632567186 +0200
@@ -458,7 +458,7 @@
             flags = flags | socket.AI_PASSIVE

         if not unix_socket:
-            addrs = socket.getaddrinfo(host, port, 0, socket.SOCK_STREAM,
+            addrs = socket.getaddrinfo(host, int(port), 0, socket.SOCK_STREAM,
                     socket.IPPROTO_TCP, flags)
             if not addrs:
                 raise Exception("Could not resolve host '%s'" % host)
```

items.title: Type errror in _encode_hybi when using the --heartbeat parameter
items.body:
When using the `--heartbeat` option, every N seconds, websockify gives us a nice `TypeError: can't concat bytes to str` because the value sent from `send_ping()` is a `str` and not a `bytes`.

```
  File "/opt/websockify/websockify/websocketproxy.py", line 180, in do_proxy
    self.send_ping()
  File "/opt/websockify/websockify/websockifyserver.py", line 211, in send_ping
    self.request.ping(data)
  File "/opt/websockify/websockify/websocket.py", line 447, in ping
    self._sendmsg(0x9, data)
  File "/opt/websockify/websockify/websocket.py", line 688, in _sendmsg
    frame = self._encode_hybi(opcode, msg)
  File "/opt/websockify/websockify/websocket.py", line 767, in _encode_hybi
    return header + buf
TypeError: can't concat bytes to str
```

Here's an example of fix. It might need to be applied to pong too.

```diff
diff --git a/websockify/websocketproxy.py b/websockify/websocketproxy.py
index 6c17c10..febf7b3 100644
--- a/websockify/websocketproxy.py
+++ b/websockify/websocketproxy.py
@@ -177,7 +177,7 @@ Traffic Legend:
                 now = time.time()
                 if now > self.heartbeat:
                     self.heartbeat = now + self.server.heartbeat
-                    self.send_ping()
+                    self.send_ping("".encode())
 
             if tqueue: wlist.append(target)
             if cqueue or c_pend: wlist.append(self.request)

```

items.title: 100% cpu usage
items.body:
There seems to be an issue in the python 0.8.0 version which occasionally causes websockify to get stuck at 100% cpu usage. The problem disappears when reverting to 0.7.0. This has happened on both a Centos 6 server, and a Ubuntu server. Normally cpu usage is < 2% per websockify process.

Here is the stack trace (probably not useful):

#0  0x0000712e54be059d in PyEval_EvalFrameEx ()
   from /usr/lib64/libpython2.6.so.1.0
#1  0x0000712e54be5647 in PyEval_EvalCodeEx ()
   from /usr/lib64/libpython2.6.so.1.0
#2  0x0000712e54be3a94 in PyEval_EvalFrameEx ()
   from /usr/lib64/libpython2.6.so.1.0
#3  0x0000712e54be5647 in PyEval_EvalCodeEx ()
   from /usr/lib64/libpython2.6.so.1.0
#4  0x0000712e54be3a94 in PyEval_EvalFrameEx ()
   from /usr/lib64/libpython2.6.so.1.0
#5  0x0000712e54be4b7f in PyEval_EvalFrameEx ()
   from /usr/lib64/libpython2.6.so.1.0
#6  0x0000712e54be4b7f in PyEval_EvalFrameEx ()
   from /usr/lib64/libpython2.6.so.1.0
#7  0x0000712e54be4b7f in PyEval_EvalFrameEx ()
   from /usr/lib64/libpython2.6.so.1.0
#8  0x0000712e54be5647 in PyEval_EvalCodeEx ()
   from /usr/lib64/libpython2.6.so.1.0
#9  0x0000712e54b78ca0 in ?? () from /usr/lib64/libpython2.6.so.1.0
#10 0x0000712e54b51c63 in PyObject_Call () from /usr/lib64/libpython2.6.so.1.0
#11 0x0000712e54b646af in ?? () from /usr/lib64/libpython2.6.so.1.0
#12 0x0000712e54b51c63 in PyObject_Call () from /usr/lib64/libpython2.6.so.1.0

The process doesn't seem to be stuck...it exits normally when the user disconnects.

Here is the process listing for a few websockify processes:

root     29597 24.0  0.0 196368  9216 ?        R    09:07  38:01 python /home/packages/websockify-master/websockify.py
root     29599  0.3  0.0 196500  9404 ?        S    09:07   0:35 python /home/packages/websockify-master/websockify.py

Both processes here have been running 2.5hrs. One has used 38 minutes of cpu time during that interval, and the other just 35 seconds. This is not to do with usage...even with our highest packet throughput these processes typically only use 2% of cpu, even with 0.8.0. I think there is some factor that is occasionally causing 0.8.0 to sometimes use all the cpu time.

items.title: Using websockify with NAT for multiple VNC servers across different PCs
items.body:
Hello,
I have a question regarding usage of websockify with NAT: say that I need to have a publicly available HTTPS server which sits in front of the NAT clients. In this scenario, one NAT client is actually PC with running VNC server and there can be many clients like this. Lets say that adding NAT client(s) does not have to be 'dynamic' (on the fly) - it is desirable, but not mandatory. 

Is it possible (and if yes - how?) that users from the outside world, sees only HTTPS server (some login page) and depending on selected NAT client (VNC server) be connected to it. I manage to do this using a port from the pool of opened ports in the given range, so external user may connect to VNC behind NAT using websocket. 

My client however is concerned that this is a security breach (due multiple opened ports for websockify to use) and would prefer that we use only one websockify port to achieve this. Plus, that port must not be available from the public network. In short, he would prefer that 443 is used for both HTTPS server (NGINX) and also websockify to target multiple VNC servers behind NAT. Additionally, multiple users can access such system at the same time. I, on the other hand am not convinced that this is possible (at least part considering sharing 443 between HTTPS server and websockify). 

I tried to find a solution on google, but the closest thing I found is to use HTTPS server that targets multiple VNCs by tampering systemd processes - but even in this solution, different ports on HTTPS server were used for different VNC servers (each target VNC server has dedicated VNC port at HTTPS server PC); and number of possible VNC clients is measured in 100s, so extending number of daemons that runs  websockify is not practical (at least I think so), plus, most of the time users are idle and not using a connection.

Thank you all in advance.

Best regards

items.title: WebSocket message with empty payload misinterpreted as close message
items.body: As of commit 8a697622495fd319582cd1c604e7eb2cc0ac0ef6, a WebSocket message with payload length zero causes the connection to be closed (“Client closed connection”). This seems to be inconsistent with the specification and with the previous behavior of websockify.

items.title: Websocket token list doesn't play well with reverse proxy
items.body:
NoVNC and apache reverse proxy for a single vnc server works fine:
Apache:
` ProxyPass /vnc http://cacti.cmslandbh.local:8787`
` ProxyPassReverse /vnc http://cacti.cmslandbh.local:8787`
` ProxyPass /websockify ws://cacti.cmslandbh.local:8787 retry=3`
` ProxyPassReverse /websockify ws://cacti.cmslandbh.local:8787`

In the terminal I start novnc:
`/var/www/html/novnc/utils/websockify/websockify.py --web /var/www/html/novnc 8787 scada:5900 &`

However if I would like to run another instance, I can't as websockify is hard-coded to look for example.com/websockify. I can rename example.com/vnc to example.com/notvnc or even example.com/subdirectory/whatisvnc and the page would load and it would work, as long as example.com/websockify was there. However example.com/websockify cannot be renamed or re-located. For example the following would not work (page loads, but can't connect to vnc host) even though a different port is used and can connect to it directly:

Apache:
`ProxyPass /directory/vnc http://cacti.cmslandbh.local:8686`
`ProxyPassReverse /directory/vnc http://cacti.cmslandbh.local:8686`
`ProxyPass /directory/websockify ws://cacti.cmslandbh.local:8686 retry=3`
`ProxyPassReverse /directory/websockify ws://cacti.cmslandbh.local:8686`

Since having multiple instances of novnc and websocket running didn't work I tried to go the token list route, but was unable to get websockify to work at all within a reverse proxy - even though it worked just fine using a single connection via terminal. Connecting directly to the server internally works as expected, but not through reverse proxy.

`/var/www/html/novnc/utils/websockify/websockify.py --web /var/www/html/novnc --target-config /var/www/html/novnc/token.list 8787 &`


Running Apache with the proxy  & proxy_wstunnel modules. 

I am not sure what logs are needed, so here are some screenshots of firefox output. 
Connecting directly to the novnc hosted server:
![successful](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32741474/31512625-a101d4d2-af59-11e7-8d98-45e908a38850.PNG)

items.title: Websockify behind one iptables bridge problem
items.body:
Hello !

I've a working novnc + websockify service on a debian server.
When I'm connecting directly on the IP of the server over http://debian1:6080/ it's working perfectly.

However, when I'm using a debian bridge on my gateway ethernet link, it's no more working.
The debian iptables bridging is something I'm using since 20 years without any problem on TCP or UDP flow, it's the first time one TCP protocol is failing :)

Did someone have any idea why it's not working ? here are my firewall settings on the debian bridge who is filtering the internet paquets :


# Create special chain KEEP_STATE
iptables -N KEEP_STATE
iptables -F KEEP_STATE

# Drop bad states
iptables -A KEEP_STATE -m state --state INVALID -j DROP
iptables -A KEEP_STATE -m state --state RELATED,ESTABLISHED -j ACCEPT

# Deny bad packets
iptables -A FORWARD -p tcp --tcp-flags ALL FIN,URG,PSH -m limit --limit 5/minute -j LOG --log-level notice --log-prefix "NMAP-XMAS: "
iptables -A FORWARD -p tcp --tcp-flags ALL FIN,URG,PSH -j DROP
iptables -A FORWARD -p tcp --tcp-flags SYN,FIN SYN,FIN -m limit --limit 5/minute -j LOG --log-level notice --log-prefix "SYN/FIN: "
iptables -A FORWARD -p tcp --tcp-flags SYN,FIN SYN,FIN -j DROP
iptables -A FORWARD -p tcp --tcp-flags SYN,RST SYN,RST -m limit --limit 5/minute -j LOG --log-level notice --log-prefix "SYN/RST: "
iptables -A FORWARD -p tcp --tcp-flags SYN,RST SYN,RST -j DROP

# Drop RST/ACKs to limit OS detection through pinging
iptables -A FORWARD -p tcp --tcp-flags RST RST,ACK -m limit --limit 5/minute -j LOG --log-level notice --log-prefix "RST/ACK: "
iptables -A FORWARD -p tcp --tcp-flags RST RST,ACK -j DROP

# Pass all boxes to the keep_state chain
iptables -A FORWARD -j KEEP_STATE

# Allow all outgoing traffic
iptables -A FORWARD -s 1.2.3.0/25 -j ACCEPT

# NoVNC WebSocket
iptables -A FORWARD -p tcp -d 1.2.3.9 --dport 6080 -j ACCEPT

# Set to drop all packets not accepted by rules above
iptables -A FORWARD -j DROP

items.title: Error during WebSocket handshake: Sent non-empty 'Sec-WebSocket-Protocol' header but no response was received
items.body:
The WebSockify bridge of noVNC seems to be broken since commit 4099949984eb80ef33c2d0dd216991124975a5d2.

The error that appears in Chrome's console is:

```js
websock.js:278 WebSocket connection to 'wss://janitor.technology/websockify' failed: Error during WebSocket handshake: Sent non-empty 'Sec-WebSocket-Protocol' header but no response was received
```

I had a look at the headers received from WebSockify's server, and indeed it seems that `Sec-WebSocket-Protocol` is no longer being sent.

Before 4099949984eb80ef33c2d0dd216991124975a5d2:

```
HTTP/1.1 101 Switching Protocols
Server: WebSockify Python/2.7.12
Date: Tue, 07 Feb 2017 15:52:33 GMT
Upgrade: websocket
Connection: Upgrade
Sec-WebSocket-Accept: yHBB/hXTWGaTjk29VQhWk2not24=
Sec-WebSocket-Protocol: binary
```

After 4099949984eb80ef33c2d0dd216991124975a5d2:

```
HTTP/1.1 101 Switching Protocols
Upgrade: websocket
Connection: Upgrade
Sec-WebSocket-Accept: ZefPJQjbgtmJGvzKFp7JvLWpDvI=
```

Maybe it could help to continue sending `Sec-WebSocket-Protocol: binary` in the WebSocket headers? Or am I doing something wrong here?
